country.name: Solomon Islands
country.background: The UK established a protectorate over the Solomon Islands in the 1890s. Some of the most bitter fighting of World War II occurred on this archipelago. Self-government was achieved in 1976 and independence two years later. Ethnic violence, government malfeasance, and endemic crime have undermined stability and civil society. In June 2003, then Prime Minister Sir Allan KEMAKEZA sought the assistance of Australia in reestablishing law and order; the following month, an Australian-led multinational force arrived to restore peace and disarm ethnic militias. The Regional Assistance Mission to the Solomon Islands (RAMSI) has generally been effective in restoring law and order and rebuilding government institutions.

geo.note: strategic location on sea routes between the South Pacific Ocean, the Solomon Sea, and the Coral Sea; on 2 April 2007 an undersea earthquake measuring 8.1 on the Richter scale occurred 345 km WNW of the capital Honiara; the resulting tsunami devastated coastal areas of Western and Choiseul provinces with dozens of deaths and thousands dislocated; the provincial capital of Gizo was especially hard hit

location.desc: Oceania, group of islands in the South Pacific Ocean, east of Papua New Guinea

geo.climate: tropical monsoon; few extremes of temperature and weather
geo.terrain: mostly rugged mountains with some low coral atolls
geo.resources: fish, forests, gold, bauxite, phosphates, lead, zinc, nickel
geo.issues: deforestation; soil erosion; many of the surrounding coral reefs are dead or dying

people.ethnic-groups: Melanesian 94.5%, Polynesian 3%, Micronesian 1.2%, other 1.1%, unspecified 0.2% (1999 census)
people.religions: Church of Melanesia 32.8%, Roman Catholic 19%, South Seas Evangelical 17%, Seventh-Day Adventist 11.2%, United Church 10.3%, Christian Fellowship Church 2.4%, other Christian 4.4%, other 2.4%, unspecified 0.3%, none 0.2% (1999 census)
people.languages: Melanesian pidgin (in much of the country is lingua franca), English (official but spoken by only 1%-2% of the population), 120 indigenous languages

government.government-type: parliamentary democracy and a Commonwealth realm

capital.name: Honiara
capital.time-difference: UTC+11 (16 hours ahead of Washington, DC during Standard Time)

government.administrative-divisions: 9 provinces and 1 capital territory*; Central, Choiseul, Guadalcanal, Honiara*, Isabel, Makira, Malaita, Rennell and Bellona, Temotu, Western
government.legal-system: mixed legal system of English common law and customary law

executive.head-of-state: Queen ELIZABETH II (since 6 February 1952); represented by Governor General Frank KABUI (since 7 July 2009)
executive.cabinet: Cabinet consists of 20 members appointed by the governor general on the advice of the prime minister from among the members of parliament
executive.elections: the monarchy is hereditary; governor general appointed by the monarch on the advice of parliament for up to five years (eligible for a second term); following legislative elections, the leader of the majority party or the leader of a majority coalition usually elected prime minister by parliament; deputy prime minister appointed by the governor general on the advice of the prime minister from among the members of parliament

legislative.description: unicameral National Parliament (50 seats; members elected from single-member constituencies by popular vote to serve four-year terms)
legislative.elections: last held on 4 August 2010 (next to be held in 2014)
legislative.election-results: percent of vote by party - NA; seats by party - SIDP 14, OUR 4, SIPRA 3, RDP 3, IDP 2, DDP 2, PCP 1, PFP 1, RUPP 1, SILP 1, SINP 1, independents 17

government.membership: ACP, ADB, AOSIS, C, ESCAP, FAO, G-77, IBRD, ICAO, ICRM, IDA, IFAD, IFC, IFRCS, ILO, IMF, IMO, IOC, ITU, MIGA, OPCW, PIF, Sparteca, SPC, UN, UNCTAD, UNESCO, UPU, WFTU, WHO, WMO, WTO

representation-in-usa.chancery: 800 Second Avenue, Suite 400L, New York, NY 10017

government.flag: divided diagonally by a thin yellow stripe from the lower hoist-side corner; the upper triangle (hoist side) is blue with five white five-pointed stars arranged in an X pattern; the lower triangle is green; blue represents the ocean; green the land; and yellow sunshine; the five stars stand for the five main island groups of the Solomon Islands

anthem.name: "God Save Our Solomon Islands"
anthem.by: Panapasa BALEKANA and Matila BALEKANA/Panapasa BALEKANA

economy.overview: The bulk of the population depends on agriculture, fishing, and forestry for at least part of its livelihood. Most manufactured goods and petroleum products must be imported. The islands are rich in undeveloped mineral resources such as lead, zinc, nickel, and gold. Prior to the arrival of RAMSI, severe ethnic violence, the closing of key businesses, and an empty government treasury culminated in economic collapse. RAMSI's efforts to restore law and order and economic stability have led to modest growth as the economy rebuilds.
economy.agriculture-products: cocoa beans, coconuts, palm kernels, rice, potatoes, vegetables, fruit; timber; cattle, pigs; fish

exports.commodities: timber, fish, copra, palm oil, cocoa

imports.commodities: food, plant and equipment, manufactured goods, fuels, chemicals
imports.partners: Singapore 24.69%, Australia 23.06%, NZ 5.2%, Fiji 4.47%, Papua New Guinea 4.34%, Malaysia 3.98% (2009)

economy.exchange-rates: Solomon Islands dollars (SBD) per US dollar -

telephones.domestic: mobile-cellular telephone density is about 5 telephones per 100 persons
telephones.international: country code - 677; satellite earth station - 1 Intelsat (Pacific Ocean)

communications.broadcast: Solomon Islands Broadcasting Corporation (SIBC) is the sole TV broadcaster with 1 station; multi-channel pay-TV is available; SIBC, the public service broadcaster, operates 2 national radio stations and 2 provincial stations; 2 local commercial radio stations operating; Radio Australia is obtainable via satellite feed (2009)

transport.ports-and-terminals: Honiara, Malloco Bay, Viru Harbor, Tulaghi

military.branches: no regular military forces; Solomon Islands Police Force (2009)

issues.disputes: since 2003, RAMSI, consisting of police, military, and civilian advisors drawn from 15 countries, has assisted in reestablishing and maintaining civil and political order while reinforcing regional stability and security
